etymologies: Middle English (originally Scots and northern English): from in+ take

definitions: an amount of food, air, or another substance taken into the body
shortDefinitions: amount of substance taken into body

definitions: an act of taking something into the body

examples.text: she heard his sharp intake of breath
a protective factor is the intake of cereal fiber

shortDefinitions: act of taking something into body

definitions: a location or structure through which something is taken in, e.g., water into a channel or pipe from a river, fuel or air into an engine or machine, commodities into a place, etc.

examples.text: cut rectangular holes for the air intake

shortDefinitions: place through which something is taken in

definitions: the action of taking something in

examples.text: facilities for the intake of grain by road
